results.title: Naissance du Jour = Retreat from Love (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Summer 1928. As usual Colette settles for the summer in her beloved country house to enjoy the earthly pleasures of Provence, the company of her artist friends and time to write. Now in her 50’s, the writer is offered a last chance at love by a much younger man, Vial. Vial is also wanted by a newcomer to Colette’s circle, Helene Clement. ‘La naissance du jour’ is a biographical account of Colette’s slow acceptance of age and renouncement to love. Filmed on location at ‘La treille muscate’, Colette’s house in St Tropez.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Baraduc ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Mendelsohn.
Cast: Daniele Delorme, Jean Sorel, Dominique Sanda, Orane Demazis.

results.title: Goupi Mains Rouges = Goupi Red Hands
results.brief_description:
The clan of the Goupi rules over a small provincial town. Each of them wears a quirky nickname: Goupi Tisane (herbal tea), Goupi Cancan (chatterbox), etc  But two of the Goupi have chosen to live outside the clan: Goupi Mains Rouges (red hands), poacher and witchdoctor and Goupi Tonkin, a former colonial soldier. One day, Goupi Tisane is found murdered in the forest. ‘Goupi Mains Rouges’ is one of the great successes of French cinema of the Occupation. At a time the Vichy regime was extolling the virtues of life on the land, the film delivered a biting satire of country life and country folks.

Credits: Producer, Jean Mugeli ; director, Jacques Becker ; writer, Pierre Very ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Jean Alfaro ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Fernand Ledoux, Georges Rollin, Blanchette Brunoy, Robert Le Vigan, Line Noro, Maurice Schutz.

results.title: Ma Nuit Chez Maud = My Night with Maud
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Barbet Schroeder and Pierre Cotrell
results.brief_description:
Jean Louis, a Catholic engineer smug in his acceptance of a Pascalian wager about faith, finds his beliefs challenged by an encounter with Maud, a free-thinking divorcee. She represents desire while Francoise - who he has observed from a distance at Mass - seems to represent, for him, a path to the attainment of grace. The ambiguous conflict between instinct and reason, nature and culture is worked through in this sharply observed comedy of manners, the third of Rohmer’s ‘Moral Tales’ (filmed out of sequence) and set in a wintry Clermont-Ferrand. Although there are many ironic moments, Rohmer’s refusal to displace ambiguity with irony allows space for the viewer to find his/her own way through the thicket created between what is observed and the rationalisation of the narrator. Awards: Prix Georges Melies 1969.

Credits: Producers, Barbet Schroeder, Pierre Cotrell ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; camera assistant, Philippe Rousselot ; editor, Cecile Decugis.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Francoise Fabian, Marie-Christine Barrault, Antoine Vitez.

results.title: Une Vie = a Life
results.brief_description:
Jeanne Dandieu lives with her parents and Rosalie, the maid, in a Normandy mansion. She is rescued from drowning by Julien de la Mare. For Jeanne, it is love at first sight. She introduces him to her parents. A few months later they are engaged to be married. This hurry starts rumours in the village that Julien is only marrying to pay off his debts. Their relationship seems a happy one until the day Jeanne’s parents leave the mansion. Jeanne discovers that her husband is having an affair with Rosalie and that she is pregnant. Jeanne feigns forgiveness, but plans in secret to take her revenge.

Credits: Producers, Annie Dorfmann ; director, Alexandre Astruc ; writers, Roland Laudenbach, Alexandre Astruc ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, Roman Vlad ; costumes, Mayo, Lucilla.
Cast: Maria Schell, Christian Marquand, Antonella Lualdi, Ivan Desny, Pascale Petit, Marie-Helene Daste, Louis Arbessier, Andree Tainsy, Gerard Darrieu.

results.title: La Trace = the Trail
results.brief_description:
Joseph is a young Savoyard peasant who makes a living by crossing the Alps into Italy in the winter months selling his wares to the villagers. This story traces a winter’s itinerary as the man encounters various adventures in his always dangerous journey, but he remains oblivious to all the nuances and reverberations of social change going on around him. When he finally returns to his family after many months away, he discovers to his surprise that his village is now a part of France and it looks like a Savoyard would soon be sitting on the throne of a unified Italy. The film was originally shot in wide screen format. This copy is presented in standard screen ratio 3:4.

Credits: Producer, Claude Nedjar ; director, Bernard Favre ; writers, Bernard Favre, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Jean-Francis Gondre ; music, Marc Perrone, Nicola Piovani.
Cast: Richard Berry, Berangere Bonvoisin, Sophie Chemineau, Marc Perrone, Robin Renucci.

results.title: Pecheur D'islande = Iceland Fisherman (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Pierre Schoendoerffer and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Yann, a sailor, is in charge of the ‘Pecheur d’Islande’, a fishing boat said to be jinxed. The boat belongs to Mevel, a rich ship owner whose daughter, Gaud, is in love with Yann. After Gaud’s father becomes bankrupt, Gaud and Yann get married. But their happiness is short-lived. A week after their wedding, Yann goes back to sea while Gaud must struggle to adapt a life of endless waiting. ‘Pecheur d’Islande’ revealed to a vast audience the epic story of the fishing expeditions to the arctic seas.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Pierre Schoendoerffer ; writers, Pierre Schoendoerffer, Andre Tabet ; photography ; Raoul Coutard ; music, Charles Aznavour.
Cast: Jean-Claude Pascal, Juliette Mayhiel, Charles Vanel, Georges Poujouly.

results.title: Ak: Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Chris Marker follows the arduous location shooting of ‘Ran’, profiling Kurosawa and his collaborators, examining the director’s techniques, and placing the film in context with his previous work.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Chris Marker ; photography, Franz-Yves Marescot ; music, Toru Takemitsu.
results.description:

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro and William Gilcher
results.brief_description:
Georges Rouquier revisits the characters of his 1938 ‘Biquefarre’ 35 year later. The family whose farm was wired for electricity in the first film are still on the family spread in 1983. The plot revolves around Raoul who decides to sell the farm to take up a job as gardener with the City of Toulouse. Though documentary in technique, the film is well planned and scripted, with its amateur cast convincingly mouthing the lines given them by Rouqier.

Credits: Producer, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher ; director, Georges Rouquier ; writers, Georges Rouquier, Maria Signorini ; photography, Andre Villard ; music, Yves Gilbert
Cast: Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Roch Rouquier, Raymond Rouquier.

results.title: L'adolescente = the Adolescent
results.brief_description:
L’Adolescente’ was the second directorial stint for film star Jeanne Moreau. Marie, a twelve-year old girl, spends the long summer holiday in the country on the eve of WWII. Her interest for games with the village children is distracted by the presence of Alexandre, a young doctor.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jeanne Moreau ; writers, Henriette Jelinek, Jeanne Moreau ; photography, Pierre Gautard ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Laetitia Chauveau, Simone Signoret, Edith Clever, Jacques Weber, Francis Huster, Jean-Francois Balmer, Michel Blanc, Hugues Quester, Jacques Rispal, Maurice Baquet, Roger Blin.

results.title: Le Miroir a Deux Faces = the Mirror Has Two Faces
results.brief_description:
A rather unambitious schoolmaster, living with his mother, marries a very plain woman. After six dreary years of marriage, the wife is transformed into a beauty by plastic surgery only to see her husband’s indifference turn into jealousy.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire ; director, Andre Cayatte ; writers, Andre Cayatte, Gerard Oury, Denis Perret, Jean Meckert ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Michele Morgan, Bourvil, Ivan Desny, Elisabeth Manet, Sandra Milo, Sylvie, Jane Marken, Carette.
